comments.commentBody: This is a Saturday? I'll not say how fast I completed this. It'd be in poor taste.

"Republicans in Congress would probably eliminate rules that require a minimum package of benefits for all insurance plans and allow states to determine what insurers would have to include. Mr. Trump has said he’d like to encourage the sale of insurance across state lines, a policy likely to make coverage more skimpy but less expensive for many customers. Republicans would also like to expand tax incentives for people to save money for health expenses."

The scam of cheap heath care insurance was always peace of mind at a cheap rate until the insured actually needed health care. Then, rooms filled with agents employed to find reasons to deny coverage went to work and those who thought they had cheap coverage found out they had very little or no coverage at all. Obama attempted to fix this as Hillary Clinton had attempted many years before. It seems to be too complex for the average American to understand and therefore easy to politicize. Obama and the Democrats have always been too intellectual for half of the country...hate is so much easier to wrap your brain around.

We are the ONLY modern western country to not have free or affordable universal health care for its citizens!

We can afford trillions for military contractors but we tell our citizens to go live at the nearest cemetery.

The heartlessness and greed at the center of our govt is mind-boggling!

Ben Carson is not merely the worst possible lobbyist for fighting racist housing policies. He's a champion of diversity only in that he serves as a bad example in a surprisingly diverse number of areas.

The list of things he gets wrong is astounding. He believes that being gay is a choice, because straight convicts who are raped in prison come out gay. Evolution is devil talk. The Big Bang is a fairy tale. Global warming doesn’t exist. There is no racism: black people get no respect due to lack of education. Planned Parenthood is a conspiracy to kill black babies.

This is the man who tried to acquire some gritty street cred by claiming he tried to stab a childhood friend to death, and who survived only due to a large belt buckle. The lack of evidence for such an attack made him angry, because no one would believe that he was homicidal.

During a holdup at a Popeye’s, he says he told the gunman, “I believe you want the guy behind the counter.” In a way, I guess that was helpful.

If anyone is expecting Ben Carson to speak coherently about the plight of poor African American people in public housing, they will have a long wait. The wait will be even longer when every other cabinet appointment of the incoming ego-in-chief makes similar outrageous statements. It appears that every member of the Cabinet of the Deplorables is especially ignorant in their areas of responsibility.

At least color will not matter in the new world order. The future is black for everyone.

Mr. Carson's stance on homosexuality is truly puzzling when one considers that his close business associate, Armstrong Williams, has been involved in at least two scandals involving sex with men.  He was sued for sexual harassment by a male physical trainer.  That the case was settled out of court was well documented in the Washington Post. David Brock, the conservative and gay author of the conservative hit piece, The Real Anita Hill, documents Williams sexual advances toward him in his book, Blinded by the Right.  This is an example of either extreme naïveté or willful ignorance.

Agree totally that the future is black for everyone. The nominee's for all posts are scary to all thinking Americans. Can't wait to see how those racist Trump supporters like what's almost certain to happen to benefits that would help them. This millionaire cabinet is not for these good old boys! This coming from a white Souther who supported Hillary knowing it was a loss cause in this state.

Gemli wrote: "He [Carson] believes (...) there is no racism: black people get no respect due to lack of education."

Actually, there is some truth to it. What many people perceive as anti-black racism is very often about class and cultural issues, not about race/skin color. The vast, vast majority of white people in America would have no problem whatsoever to have black neighbors who are university professors, doctors, lawyers, journalists, and such.

I think that Carson experienced that his life changed when he became a successful and respectable doctor - suddenly no one viewed his as inferior. And that is why he believes what he believes. You cannot just dismiss that man's experience, Gemli. Carson may know more about racism, its presence or absence, and the reasons for it, than you.

I respect hi, for one thing -- he does not subscribe to the culture of victimhood. The more black people believe they are victims, the less likely they are to overcome victimhood.
Yes.  The rush to repeal is GOP glee at giving the finger to Obama, and to hell with all the people who are going to actually DIE because of it.

Yes.  I realize the feminist movement was a self congratulating union that still wants to monopolize the conversation. Whatever they've done they've done - call it victory and go home. I think it better that today's kids live their feminism than use history didactically.
I endorse this nit.

Trump is obviously either clueless, oblivious or both. Otherwise, before the election he would have consulted with health care experts and had a potentially workable plan in place. Instead, he just wants to let Congress decide. Well, if the result is "Ryan care" maybe Trump will actually listen to what the actuaries in the CBO have to say about a large increase to the national debt and no funding mechanism for whatever the federal government decides will be its contribution to the pot. Then again, so far he hasn't signaled an inclination to fight the most conservative  elements of his party despite his campaign rhetoric.
Jan. 21st. women's march.

The idea that this will be a country of robot repairmen or perpetual job retainers is as ludicrous as the idea that we would become a nation of white collar professionals (a dream pushed by pro-NAFTA politicians in the late 1980s and early 1990s).

I don't know what is going to happen. I never looked at it, but if someone told me that 95% of jobs in 1880 are now gone I would not be surprised. So we simply don't know what would happen. But what I do know is that we will never have a nation of "STEM graduates" who all make tons of money and are secure in the new economy. It's a fantasy. Nor can we reasonably expect people to constant retrain after the stuff they already trained for gets automated in 3 years.
I am a STEM graduate and my job was outsource to India. So much for getting educated as a sure thing!

BB- thank you.  You stated exactly why, after four mammograms, I decided never again.  It's an unpleasant exchange with my doctor now as she becomes increasingly insistent that I need to have mammograms, and I remind her it is my choice, and I choose not to have my healthy tissue crushed and subject to radiation.  I am certain there have been no studies into whether mammography might trigger or contribute to cancer--who would fund such a venture?  But I remember the sick feeling deep in my skin for weeks after my last mammogram.

It would help if news media followed the (usual though not invariable) practice of the New York Times by reporting not only on what happened but making clear how we know.
For instance: Here's a real argument. One person said "Clinton got more popular votes than Trump, by close to 3 million" and the other said, "No, that's not true, Trump won the popular vote." Neither could cite anything besides a news report they recalled. So, instead of just repeating that 2.8 million popular vote lead each time, can't reporters, and even columnists, explain that the popular vote kept getting counted as mail ballots came in and provisional ballots were evaluated, that official state websites posted final totals, and that the final totals based on these can be found at the Cook report -- and that you personally can check these results against official state sites?
That's one example. Yes, it's important to speak truth to power. But it's also important to model for your audience how truth is established on the basis of evidence.

This comment from G.H. is another example of why the press needs to do its job of continuing to present fact in order to counter fiction - Clinton got 50% or more of the vote in 14 states as well as DC (you can look it up on the NYT website: http://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/president). This nonsense that all of her 2.8 million more votes came from California is just that. Time to put it to bed.

@G.H.
Except that's not the reason why there's an Electoral College. It's there because the founders had an uneasiness about the possible excesses of direct democracy. That's also why the Senate wasn't originally directly elected. Further, the electoral college ultimately doesn't give weight to small vs. large states but swing states vs. secure ones.

"almost no stories go on to state that this majority is in California alone."
Because it isn't true. Votes are fungible.

What's also interesting is if all the votes except NY and CA were counted, Trump won by more than 3 million votes. Shows how really divided we are.  Dems should keep this in mind: pay attention to the rest of the country or you will continue to lose.

"The Police" constitute a gray fuzzy area-- separate culture.  If they do something wrong, who do you call?  Why the police, of course!  As a separate culture, "The Police" are not subject to the same sort of accountability to "law and order" as are the government and the governed.  They are a presence that is always in the dark, never fully knowable.  Trampling on Civil Rights is what the French call, 'bavure.'  Coming from the verb to dribble or drool-- something that can't be helped if one wishes to eat.  Police brutality is a result of creating a Police Culture.  As long as the Police Culture exists (and nobody is talking about putting and end to Police Culture), there will be bavure.  A few dribbles on the tie, in the course of a meal is to be expected, unless of course, you are the tie.
It's free market politics. We are a capitalist country and so the capitalists rule. The rest of us live off of their scraps and diminishing social consciousness.
This is what happens when you pass game changing legislation without compromise, reading the legislation, and changing the rules in the Senate. You can that Harry Reid for this.
Obama has no one to thank except himself for listening to the bad advice of Harry Reid and Nancy Pelosi.
And if your conjecture is true, and I hope it is for "health care sake", the Dems, placid as ever,  will sit back and let it happen. Somehow they need to grow a backbone.

The Buzzfeed report is not the first news article to be attacked by Trump, it is his way of operating, he has a long record of suing those whom write critical articles about him.

Even though a public person is subject to different interpretation of libel laws than the the ordinary person, he has his attorneys sue for large sums, the cost of defending is beyond that of many writers. This intimidates the press and the free dissemination of news about him. It is not much different than the Fascist parties techniques of the 1930s, shut down the news that you do not like, and the misdeeds, corruption, criminal behavior of the politicians is hidden from the public.

Trump is a master of this, and the news organizations are allowing him to get away with it, it is a blot on their duty to keep the public informed. As we saw, there was very little investigative journalism about Trump, but almost daily article about Clinton. Trump was whitewashed by the press, a disservice to us all.

We are now being subjected to daily tirades attacking any negative news about him, and worse yet a congressman proposed that CNN fire a reporter for "Disrespecting Trump." The very core of Fascist dictatorship practices. Suddenly the dictator can not be criticized, he can not be held accountable for his actions, this is not the country is was raised in it the one we fought in WWII. FDR was criticized by the GOP time after time, no suggested that was unpatriotic,

Nobody put a gun to Enperor Donald's head and forced him to run for office.

We pay the salary of POTUS ut of all of our taxes.

POTUS works for us, and not the other way around.

POTUS is accountable to us, and as a "public figure", is weakly protected by libel and defamation laws.

Certainly a "public figure" is subject to ridicule and commentary in the press.

The old adage is "if you can't take the heat, stay out of the kitchen."

Emperor Donald is the top chef in the kitchen, so his "cooking" is definitely going to be commented upon.

Get used to it Donnie. Either that or you are going to be suing a hundred million of us as individuals. There are a heck of a ot more of us that there are of you. How big is your legal budget? (Whatever it is, it is not big enough.)

This s how it begins in countries which eventually become authoritarian states.

I watch President Obama. I watch President Elect Trump. And I weep for America.
The Republican Health Care Plan for America:   Prayer.

They really did blow out the brains of the USA back in 1953. Three full generations, a whole lifespan of people, have since been propagandized from nursery school on to the effect that a benign personality of nature governs this nation from the far side of the sky. It's all magic, and idolatry is the only way you'll ever accomplish anything. Congress is a collection of drones who thrive from this brainwashing.
The sick and dying don't make much noise so legislators sleep quite peacefully.

It seems like their solution will just be to transition folks out of their health insurance slowly.

We found a leak in the boat, so we're blowing it up rather than patch it. But you have a 10 minute warning and a life vest each. Of course, you'll die in the water after an hour, but we can't have dependency you know. Figure it out.

Somebody always wins the Boston Marathon, against great odds and based on hard work and dedication. That doesn't mean that most people can.

I salute Ben Carson for having made it out of poverty. But the gate he came through was -- and still is -- too narrow for every poor Black person to make it through.

Howard,

"I salute Ben Carson for having made it out of poverty. But the gate he came through was -- and still is -- too narrow for every poor Black person to make it through."

The gate is as narrow for a poor White, Amerindian, Hispanic, or Armenian person. Gates are always narrower for the poor, and this is how it's supposed to be.
Unless you believe in plain and corny utopia of a paradise for all.

Obama's big mistake, and frankly many of the Dems over the years was to make ACA etc., about reform, and somewhat about access, as opposed to a moral right.  And while I think Obama's farewell speech gave us a lot to ponder as Trump takes over, it was a missed opportunity to assert that among the many rights we have as Americans, health is one of them.
Their position on Planned Parenthood says all you need to know how serious they are about public health. I think they want a population soaked in alcohol after conception by rape.
Progressives need to get control of the message. As much as I love Obama, I do not believe he and his PR team did a good PR job.

This is absolutely correct.  Why did the dems let Fox News control the discourse on Obamacare after the ACA was passed?  Why did the dems run from it, instead of aggressively selling it? Furious at Republicans and Dems--and hoping the DNC and leadership in House and Senate gets a clue.

Donald Trump could do something right now to assuage some of the concerns about the forthcoming presidency: demand that GOP leaders spell out exactly how they intend to replace Obamacare. He promised his supporters, many of whom are on the ACA, to replace the program with something cheaper and covering everyone. He famously said during the campaign: " We can't have people dying in the streets."

Mr Trump, don't settle for repeal now and " we'll get to it later." If you can imagine winning a second term, you better get this one right.

“The public has rendered judgment,” Mr. Shimkus said.“ The public did indeed speak Mr. Shimkus and fellow Republicans. By almost 3 million votes the public voted to change, but not repeal the ACA.

Unfortunately the Senate and House seem to have trouble with recognizing that. Cognitive dissonance perhaps? Does their elite health care policy provides mental health coverage?
They literally run the country to empower psychopaths.
Get the goat out of the house? Really!! The only goat doing damage in this case is the Republican majority in the house and senate.
